titleStmt.title: Weakly implicative (fuzzy) logics I: basic properties

analytic.title: Weakly implicative (fuzzy) logics I: basic properties

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper presents two classes of propositional logics (understood as a consequence relation). First we generalize the well-known class of implicative logics of Rasiowa and introduce the class of weakly implicative logics. This class is broad enough to contain many "usual" logics, yet easily manageable with nice logical properties. Then we introduce its subclass-the class of weakly implicative fuzzy logics. It contains the majority of logics studied in the literature under the name fuzzy logic. We present many general theorems for both classes, demonstrating their usefulness and importance.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In the last decades many so-called fuzzy logics were introduced and developed. Also some well-established many-valued logics, like Łukasiewicz or Gödel-Dummett logic, have been adopted into a general framework of fuzzy logics (as extension of Hájek's Basic Fuzzy Logic). Since Hájek's monograph [10] the fuzzy logics are considered as mathematical non-classical logics sui juris. After

The work was supported by grant A100300503 of the Grant Agency of the Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic and by Institutional Research Plan AVOZ10300504. P. Cintula (B) Institute of Computer Science, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic, Pod Vodárenskou v ěží 2, Prague 8 182 07, Czech Republic e-mail: cintula@cs.cas.cz then the above mentioned dozens of logical systems were studied by prominent logicians and (theoretical) computer scientists. It is the opinion of the author that this development has gone to the point when we know hundreds of particular results for particular logics and so we can (and should!) generalize them and get results for classes of (fuzzy) logics.

In this paper we introduce two classes of logics. First, we generalize implicative logics of Rasiowa [13] and get the so-called weakly implicative logics. Although this can be viewed as a rather minor generalization, it forces us to leave the algebraic semantics and move towards semantics provided by the so-called logical matrices (weakly implicative logics are not (in general) algebraizable in the sense of Blok and Piggozzi [3]). From the point of view of Abstract Algebraic Logic (see survey [8]) this is a subclass of the so-called equivalential logics (more comments on this topic are before the definition of weakly implicative logics). Roughly speaking, equivalential logics "deal with equivalence/equality" and weakly implicative logics "deal with preorder/order". We show that they can be viewed as the "logics of ordered matrices". In this paper the class of weakly implicative logics serves as a background for the second class of weakly implicative fuzzy logics (WIFL). Thus we leave more thorough investigation of this class of logics (and especially its connection with other classes of logics known in AAL) for some future paper.

The class of WIFL is an attempt to formally define and delimit an informal notion of fuzzy logic. We try to provide mathematical arguments demonstrating the importance of this class of logics (whereas philosophical, methodological, and pragmatical reasons are to be find in a joint paper by the author and Libor B ěhounek [2]). We define WIFL as a class of logics complete w.r.t. linearly ordered matrices and we show several equivalent definitions using well-known concepts of the theory of the fuzzy logics, like prelinearity property or subdirect decomposition theorem.

The fact that WIFL is defined formally and closed under intersection, allows us to speak about the weakest fuzzy logic with some properties. So we can extend the known result of [7] that MTL (Monoidal t-norm logic) is an extension of FL ew (Full Lambek calculus with exchange and weakening), to the following one: MTL is the weakest fuzzy logic that extends FL ew . In fact, for each logic we can assign the weakest (weakly implicative) fuzzy logic extending it. This turns out to be an important methodological guideline: the weakest fuzzy logic having some property seems to be a good starting point for the investigation of the property in the context of fuzzy logics.

The rest of the paper is devoted to the study of (variants of) Local Deduction Theorem and of the unary connective (the so-called Baaz delta) which is heavily used in fuzzy logic literature. In both cases the two above-defined classes of logics serve as our "playgrounds" and the achieved results support our belief that they are well-defined and have their "right for existence".

In many aspects this paper gives only basic definitions and shows directions towards possible future development. Some issues are already (partially) handled by the author's PhD. thesis [4], especially predicate weakly implicative (fuzzy) logics, embedding (some) of the existing fuzzy logic into the proposed general framework, and general concept of expansions of fuzzy logics by rational truth constants. Other important direction of the research leads towards exploration of the relation between WIFL and AAL.

div.head: Weakly implicative logics
div.p: We start with some obligatory introductory definitions. For a comprehensive survey into the theory of the general approaches towards the logical systems, consequence relations, logical matrices, etc., see Czelakowski's book [5] or the survey to AAL [8]. In the first subsection we introduce weakly implicative logics. Then, in the second subsection, we present the semantics for them (using the well-known notion of logical matrix).

div.head: Syntax
div.p: Definition 1 A propositional language L is a triple (VAR, C, a), where VAR is a non-empty set 1 of the (propositional) variables, C is a nonempty set of the (propositional) connectives, and a is a function assigning a natural number to each element of C.

The set VAR is usually taken as a fixed countable set, and so we usually define the propositional language L as a pair (C, a). Later on, we fix symbols for some basic connectives (→, ∧, ⊥, . . . ) together with their arities and then we define a propositional language just as a set of these connectives. Sometimes we write (c, n) ∈ L instead of c ∈ C and a(c) = n. Definition 2 (Formula) Let L be a propositional language. The set of (propositional) formulae FOR L is the smallest set which contains VAR and is closed under connectives from C, i.e., for each (c, n) ∈ L and each ϕ 1 , . . . ,
div.formula: ϕ n ∈ FOR L we have c(ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n ) ∈ FOR L . Definition 3 (Substitution) Let L be a propositional language. A substitution is a mapping σ : FOR L → FOR L , such that σ is compatible with connectives, i.e., σ (c(ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n )) = c(σ (ϕ 1 ), . . . , σ (ϕ n )) holds for each (c, n) ∈ L.
div.p: The set of all substitutions will be denoted as SUB L .

Of course, a substitution is fully determined by its values on propositional variables. If v ∈ VAR and ϕ, ψ ∈ FOR L , then by ψ[v := ϕ] we understand the formula σ (ψ), where σ is the substitution mapping v to ϕ and mapping all the remaining propositional variables to itself. The term consecution in the following definition is from the Restall's book [14]. However, we use it in a very simplified way.

div.head: Definition 4 (Consecution)
div.p: A consecution in the propositional language L is a pair < X, ϕ >, where X ⊆ FOR L and ϕ ∈ FOR L . The set of all consecutions will be denoted as CON L .

Instead of < X, ϕ > we write X ϕ. Since CON L = P(FOR L )×FOR L , each subset X of CON L can be understood as a relation between the sets of formulae and formulae (we identify the set X and the relation X in the following way X X ϕ iff (X ϕ) ∈ X ). For X ⊆ FOR L , X ⊆ CON L and substitution σ we fix the following convention:
-By σ (X) we understand the set {σ (ϕ
div.formula: ) | ϕ ∈ X}. -By σ (X ) we understand the set {σ (X) σ (ϕ) | (X ϕ) ∈ X }. -By SUB L (X ) we denote the set σ ∈SUB L σ (X ).
div.p: Definition 5 (Logic) Let L be a propositional language. A non-empty set L ⊆ CON L is called a logic in the language L when it satisfies:
div.formula: -if ϕ ∈ X, then X L ϕ. -if Y L ϕ for each ϕ ∈ X and X L ψ, then Y L ψ. -if X L ϕ, then σ (X) L σ (ϕ) for each σ ∈ SUB L .
div.p: Thus the logic is a structural (substitution-invariant) consequence relation in the sense of Tarski. The elements of a logic are consecutions. Sometimes, when the logic L is known from the context, we write just instead of L . We denote the set {ϕ | ∅ L ϕ} as T HM(L). Now we introduce the notion of an axiomatic system. Observe that both axiomatic systems and logics are objects of the same kind. Both are sets of consecutions closed under substitution, logics only satisfy two more conditions (of a consequence relation). This observation simplifies formulations of some upcoming theorems. Definition 6 (Axiomatic system) Let L be a propositional language. An axiomatic system AS in language L is a non-empty set AS ⊆ CON L , which is closed under arbitrary substitution (i.e., SUB L (AS) = AS).
The elements of AS of the form X ϕ ∈ AS are called axioms for X = ∅, n-ary deduction rules for |X| = n, and infinitary deduction rules otherwise.
An axiomatic system is said to be finite if there is a finite set X ⊆ AS such that SUB L (X ) = AS. Furthermore, an axiomatic system is said to be finitary if all its deduction rules are finite.

div.head: Definition 7 (Proof)
div.p: Let L be a propositional language and AS an axiomatic system in L. A proof of the formula ϕ in theory T is a well-founded tree labelled by formulae; the root is labelled by ϕ and the leaves by either axioms or elements of T; and if a node is labelled by ψ and its preceding nodes are labelled by
div.formula: ψ 1 , ψ 2 , . . . then < {ψ 1 , ψ 2 , . . . }, ψ > ∈ AS. We write T p AS ϕ if there is a proof of ϕ in T.
div.p: By theory we mean just a set of formulas. The fact that tree is well-founded just means that there is no infinitely long branch.

div.head: Lemma 1
div.p: Let L be a propositional language and AS an axiomatic system in L. Then p AS is the least logic containing AS.
Proof Obviously p AS is a logic and AS ⊆ p AS . The proof that for each logic
div.formula: L if AS ⊆ L, then p AS ⊆ L is simple: if T p AS ϕ,
div.p: then there is a proof of ϕ in T, by the induction over the well-founded relation representing the proof we show that for each formula ψ, being a label of some node, we have T L ψ.

div.head: Definition 8 (Presentation)
div.p: Let L be a propositional language, AS an axiomatic system in L, and L a logic in L. We say that AS is an axiomatic system for (a presentation of) the logic
div.formula: L iff L = p AS .
div.p: Logic is said to be finitely axiomatizable (finitary) if it has some finite (finitary) presentation.

Observe that each logic has at least one presentation. Now we show that our definition of finitary logics coincides with the usual one: Lemma 2 (Finitary logic) Let L be a logic. Then L is finitary iff for each theory T and formula ϕ we have: if T ϕ, then there is finite T ⊆ T such that T ϕ.

Proof If L is finitary, then there is its finitary presentation AS. Observe that for each finitary AS the proofs are always finite (because the tree has no infinite branch and because AS is finitary, each node has finitely many preceding nodes and so we can use König's Lemma to get that the tree is finite). The reverse direction is almost straightforward.

Observe that in the finitary case we can linearize the tree, i.e., define the notion of the proof in the usual way. Our notion of the proof allows us to illustrate one important (and usually overlooked) feature of our way of introducing a logic. The deduction rule {ψ 1 , ψ 2 , . . . } ϕ gives us a way how to construct a proof of ϕ using proofs of ψ 1 , ψ 2 , . . . . However, the "meta-rule": from ψ 1 , ψ 2 , . . . get ϕ only tells us that if there are proofs of ψ 1 , ψ 2 , . . . , then there is a proof of ϕ without any hint how to construct it. It should be stressed that rules are rules of inference between formulae, whereas "meta-rules" are in fact rules of the inference between consecutions. The conditions in Definition 5 are in fact meta-rules of consequence.

div.head: Definition 9
div.p: Let L 1 and L 2 be propositional languages and L i a logic in L i . We say that L 2 is an expansion of L 1 iff L 1 ⊆ L 2 . The expansion is axiomatic if L 2 is axiomatized by logic L 1 (understood as an axiomatic system) with some additional axioms.
The expansion is conservative if for each theory T and formula ϕ in language L 1 we have:
div.formula: T L 2 ϕ entails T L 1 ϕ. In that case L 1 is also called the L 1 -fragment of L 2 .
div.p: If L 1 = L 2 , we speak about extension rather than about expansion. Now we define the crucial concept of this paper: the notion of a weakly implicative logic. We assume that there is a binary connective → in the propositional language. There is an obvious generalization of this approach; if we drop the condition of the presence of the connective → in language and following the AAL tradition, we would understand the term ϕ → ψ as a set of formulae of two propositional variables, where the formula ϕ is substituted for the first one and the formula ψ for the second one. Observe that some theorems proven in this paper remain theorems under this interpretation (more thorough development of this generalization will be a subject of an upcoming paper). It is easy to see that in this more general approach (which we will not pursuit in this paper) the defined class of logics would be a subclass of the so-called equivalential logics, and in the more specific approach (we use in this paper) the class of logics defined by the following definition is a subclass of the so-called finitely equivalential logics. In fact, all weakly implicative logics are finitely equivalential logics with the set of equivalence formulae E = {p → q, q → p}. The name, weakly implicative logics, is inspired by the notion of implicative logics by Helena Rasiowa,2 see her book [13]. As we will see, our notion is really a generalization of her notion (her only additional assumption is ϕ ψ → ϕ).

Definition 10 (Weakly implicative logics) Let L be a propositional language, such that (→, 2) ∈ L and let L be a logic in L. We say that L is a weakly implicative logic iff the following consecutions are elements of L:
div.formula: (Ref) L ϕ → ϕ (MP) ϕ, ϕ → ψ L ψ (WT) ϕ → ψ, ψ → χ L ϕ → χ (Cng i c ) ϕ → ψ, ψ → ϕ L c(χ 1 , . . . , χ i-1 , ϕ, . . . , χ n ) → → c(χ 1 , . . . , χ i-1 , ψ, . . . , χ n ) for each (c, n) ∈ L and each i ≤ n.
div.p: (Ref) is for reflexivity, (MP) is for modus ponens, (WT) is for weak transitivity, and (Cng) is for congruence. Let (c, n) ∈ L, then by (Cng c ) we understand the set of consecutions {(Cng i c ) | i ≤ n}. Furthermore, by (Cng L ) we understand the set of consecutions c∈L (Cng c ). Observe that we assume neither Exchange nor Weakening nor Contraction as a rule for implication. However, we have all of them as meta-rules, i.e., the connective → is by no means an internalization of . We can say that our approach towards corresponds to derivability from assumptions in some Hilbert's style calculus. It is defined in the same fashion as the Hilbert calculi for particular substructural logics. This paper can be seen as a contribution to the general (universal, abstract) theory of these calculi. For another (even more) general treatment of this topic, see Restall's book [14]. Let ϕ ↔ ψ be a shortcut for {ϕ → ψ, ψ → ϕ}.

div.head: Lemma 3 (Alternative definition)
div.p: The set of consecutions (Cng L ) can be equivalently replaced by one of the following sets of consecutions:
div.formula: -ϕ 1 ↔ ψ 1 , . . . , ϕ n ↔ ψ n c(ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n ) → c(ψ 1 , . . . , ψ n ) for each (c, n) ∈ L.
div.p: ϕ ↔ ψ χ → χ for each formula χ ∈ FOR L , where χ is a result of replacing some occurrence of subformula ϕ with formula ψ in formula χ .

The proof is simple. Notice that the second part of this lemma can be understood as a substitution rule and we will use it heavily in the formal proofs in this paper. Now we list several simple lemmata with rather trivial proofs.

div.head: Lemma 4
div.p: Let L be a weakly implicative logic in a language L and L a logic in a language L , which is an expansion of L. Then L is a weakly implicative logic iff for each n-ary connective c in L \ L and each i ≤ n we have:

div.head: Corollary 1 (Extension) An arbitrary extension of an arbitrary weakly implicative logic is a weakly implicative logic.
div.p: Lemma 5 (Intersection) The intersection of an arbitrary system of weakly implicative logics is a weakly implicative logic.

div.head: Definition 11 (Consistency)
div.p: Let L be a weakly implicative logic. A theory T is consistent if there is formula ϕ such that T L ϕ. The logic L is consistent iff the theory ∅ is consistent.

Observe that a logic L is inconsistent iff L = CON L , i.e., each consecution is provable. Now we introduce the notion of the linear theory. In the existing fuzzy logic literature the term complete theory is usually used. However, we think that a complete theory is a different concept (also known as a maximal consistent theory). However, this notion is crucial in our paper and we want to avoid any potential confusions we decided to pick new neutral name. The reason for choosing the name "linear" will be obvious after Lemma 8.

div.head: Definition 12 (Linear theory)
div.p: Let L be a weakly implicative logic. A theory T is linear if T is consistent and for each formulae ϕ, ψ we have T ϕ → ψ or T ψ → ϕ.
To end this subsection we introduce the notion of power of the implication, to write ϕ 3 → ψ instead of ϕ → (ϕ → (ϕ → ψ)) (for example).

div.head: Definition 13
div.p: Let m be a natural number and ϕ, ψ formulae. Then the formula ϕ m → ψ is defined inductively as:
div.formula: ϕ 0 → ψ = ψ and ϕ i+1 → ψ = ϕ → (ϕ i → ψ).

div.head: Semantics
div.p: We start again by recalling some well-known definitions. The completeness theorem for weakly implicative logics (which we prove in this section) is a consequence of some more general theorem known in AAL. However, our concern is not to reprove known facts, we concentrate on the notion of linearity of a logical matrix, which (as far as the author knows) was not so deeply studied.

div.head: Definition 14 (Algebra and matrix) Let L = (C, a) be a propositional language. An algebra A = (A, C) with signature (C, a) is called L-algebra. Let us denote the realization of c in A as c A . A pair B = (A B , D B ), where A B is L-algebra and D B is a subset of A, is called L-matrix. The elements of D B are called designated elements of matrix B.
div.p: Notice that substitution can be understood as a endomorphism of the absolutely free L-algebra. We will write c B instead of c A B Definition 15 (Evaluation) Let L be a propositional language and A an L-algebra. An A-evaluation is a mapping e: FOR L → A, such that for each (c, n) ∈ L and each n-tuple of formulae ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n we have: e(c(ϕ 1 , . . . ,

Of course, each A-evaluation is fully determined by its values on propositional variables. We can understand an A-evaluation as a homomorphism from the absolutely free L-algebra to A. Again, we speak about B-evaluation instead of A B -evaluation.
div.formula: to class K iff | K ⊇ L. We say that a logic L is complete w.r.t. class K iff | K ⊆ L.
div.p: Definition 19 (L-matrices) Let L be a logic in L, T a theory in L, and B an L-matrix. We say that B is an
div.formula: L-matrix if L ⊆ | {B} .

div.head: We denote the class of L-matrices by MOD(L). Finally, we write T | L ϕ instead of T | MOD(L) ϕ and T AUT (L) instead of T AUT (MOD(L)).
div.p: Observe that for each presentation AS of logic L we have: L ⊆ | {B} iff AS ⊆ | {B} (one direction is obvious, the second one is Lemma 1). The proof of the following lemma is trivial.

div.head: Lemma 6 (Soundness)
div.formula: A logic L is sound w.r.t. class MOD(L) (i.e., if T L ϕ, then T | L ϕ). Furthermore, MOD(L) is the greatest class w.r.t. which the logic L is sound.
div.p: The proof of the following lemma is almost straightforward. Observe that the congruence relation defined in the following lemma is the so-called Leibnitz congruence (see [8]). The matrix B is said to be ordered iff the relation ≤ B is order. We denote the class of ordered L-matrixes by MOD * (L).
The matrix B is said to be linearly ordered (or just linear) iff the relation ≤ B is linear order. We denote the class of linearly ordered L-matrixes by MOD (L).

Matrices for weakly implicative logics coincide with the class of the so-called prestandard matrices (see Dunn and Hardegree [6]), whereas the ordered matrices coincides with the so-called standard matrices. The ordered matrices also coincide with the class of the so-called reduced matrices in AAL (see [8]), thus we use their notation. Obviously, MOD (L) ⊆ MOD * (L) ⊆ MOD(L). An interesting question is where the opposite of Lemma 6 holds, i.e., whether the logic L is complete w.r.t. class MOD(L). Since all weakly implicative logics are equivalential, we know that the answer is positive (see [8]). As we are interested in a stronger claim, than just completeness w.r.t. all matrices, we recall the well-known concept of a Lindenbaum-Tarski matrix and prove some of its not so well-know properties (Lemma 8 Parts (3) and ( 5)). It is also interesting to observe how the abstract concepts of AAL are rendered in our not so abstract setting.
Definition 21 (Lindenbaum-Tarski matrix) Let L be a weakly implicative logic in L, T a theory in L. We define
div.formula: [ϕ] T = {ψ | T ϕ ↔ ψ} and L T = {[ϕ] T | ϕ ∈ FOR L }. We define an L-matrix Lind T ,

div.head: where the L-algebra has the domain L T , operations c Lind
div.formula: T ([ϕ 1 ] T , . . . , [ϕ n ] T ) = [c(ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n )] T and the designated set D Lind T = {[ϕ] T | T L ϕ}.
div.p: It is obvious that the definition is sound (due to rules (Cng L ) and (MP)). Now we prove the fundamental lemma, whose parts 1-4 are consequences of the known facts about equivalential logics. However, the crucial part for us is part 5 which links the notion of the linear theory with the notion of linearity of a matrix.

div.head: Lemma 8
div.p: Let L be a weakly implicative logic, T a theory, and e an Lind T -evaluation defined as e(ϕ) = [ϕ] T . Then:
div.formula: 1. Lind T ∈ MOD(L) 2. e ∈ Mod(T, Lind T ) 3. [ϕ] ≤ Lind T [ψ] T iff T ϕ → ψ 4. Lind T ∈ MOD * (L) 5. Lind T ∈ MOD (L) iff T is a linear theory. Proof 1. We show that if X L ϕ then X | Lind T ϕ, i.e., if X L ϕ and f ∈ Mod(X, Lind T ), then f (ϕ) ∈ D Lind T . Observe that for each formula χ there is a formula χ such that f (χ ) = [χ ] T .
div.p: Let us define substitution σ by setting σ (v) = ψ ∈ f (v) (arbitrarily for each v ∈ VAR). Further we show that for each ϕ we get σ (ϕ
div.formula: ) ∈ f (ϕ): let ϕ = c(ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n ), from σ (ϕ i ) ∈ f (ϕ i ) we get σ (c(ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n )) = c(σ (ϕ 1 ), . . . σ (ϕ n )) ∈ c Lind T (f (ϕ 1 ), . . . , f (ϕ n )) = f (c(ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n )).
div.p: Thus we know that for each ϕ we get
div.formula: f (ϕ) = [σ (ϕ)] T From f ∈ Mod(X, Lind T ) we get that f (ψ) ∈ D Lind T for each ψ ∈ X and thus T σ (ψ).
div.p: From X ϕ we get σ (X) σ ϕ. Taken together, we have T σ (ϕ) and so Of course, this theorem holds for a much wider class of logics than our weakly implicative ones, for details, see [8]. Obviously in each weakly implicative logic, T HM(L) = T AUT (L). The proof of the following corollary is trivial.
div.formula: f (ϕ) = [σ (ϕ)] T ∈ D Lind T . 2. Trivial. 3. [ϕ] ≤ Lind T [ψ] T iff [ϕ] → Lind T [ψ] T ∈ D Lind T iff [ϕ → ψ] T ∈ D Lind T iff T ϕ → ψ. 4. Since [ϕ] ≤ Lind T [ψ] T and [ψ] ≤ Lind T [ϕ] T entails T ϕ ↔ ψ the proof is obvious. 5. Straightforward.

div.head: Corollary 2 Let L be a weakly implicative logic and T a theory. Then for each formula
div.formula: ϕ holds T ϕ iff T | L ϕ iff T | MOD * (L) ϕ.
div.p: Now we recall the definition of a direct and subdirect product of matrices. These definitions are obvious, if we understand a matrix as a first-order structure with functions corresponding to the operations and one unary predicate, whose realization is the set of designated elements.

Definition 22 Let L = (VAR, C, a) be a propositional language and I a (nonempty) class of L-matrices. The direct product of the matrices from I (denoted as B∈I B) is a matrix X = (X, (c X ) c∈C , D X ), where X is a cartesian product of domains of matrices from I, operations are defined pointwise, and
div.formula: (x B ) B∈I ∈ D X iff x B ∈ D B for each B ∈ I.
div.p: Furthermore, we say that the matrix X is a subdirect product of the matrices from I if there is an embedding f : X → B∈I B, such that π B (f (X)) = B holds for each B ∈ I.
By π B we mean the projection to the component B. For the proof of the following lemma, see [5,Corollary 0.3.10].

div.head: Lemma 9
div.p: Let L be a logic and I a class of L-matrices. Then each matrix X which is a subdirect product of matrices from I is an L-matrix.

div.head: Weakly implicative fuzzy logics
div.p: In the previous section we have seen that each weakly implicative logic is sound and complete w.r.t. the class of its ordered matrices. There is an obvious question, which of them are complete w.r.t. the class of its linearly ordered matrices. This will lead us to the second central definition of this paper: the notion of weakly implicative fuzzy logic.

div.head: Definition 23 (Fuzzy logics) A weakly implicative logic L is called a fuzzy
div.formula: logic if L = | MOD (L) (i.e., if the logic L is complete w.r.

div.head: t. the linearly ordered L-matrices).
div.p: The full proper name of these logics is weakly implicative fuzzy logics. Since all the logics that we will encounter from now on are weakly implicative, we sometimes just say that a logic is a fuzzy logic and not a weakly implicative fuzzy logic. Obviously, in fuzzy logics we have T HM(L) = T AUT (L) =

div.head: T AUT (MOD (L)).
div.p: There is a joint paper by the author and B ěhounek and Cintula [2] given philosophical, methodological, and pragmatical reasons for using the term fuzzy, and for formal delimitation of the existing informal class of fuzzy logics. Here we give only one example: the class of fuzzy logics includes the classical logic and that can seem a little odd. However, we think that the classical logic is a (very special) example of a fuzzy logic: fuzzy logic is a generalization of the classical logic, designed to encompass also vague predicates. Thus the classical logic is a fuzzy logic usable in those special occasions when, by chance, the realizations of all predicates are crisp. We also think that a good definition should include its limit cases and to exclude the classical logic in the general definition would be inconvenient, because most results on (non-classical) fuzzy logics hold for the classical logic as well. Now we are going to show several equivalent definitions of the class of WIFL.

Definition 24 (Linear extension) A weakly implicative logic L has linear extension property (LEP) if for each theory T and formula ϕ such that T ϕ there is a linear theory T , such that T ⊆ T and T ϕ. Reverse direction: we need to prove that L = | MOD (L) . One inclusion is trivial consequence of Theorem 1, the reverse one we prove by contradiction: assume that T ϕ. Let us take a linear supertheory T ϕ. We know that Lind T ∈ MOD (L) (from Lemma 8) and for the Lind T -evaluation e defined as e(ψ) = [ψ] T holds e ∈ Mod(T , Lind T ). This entails that also e ∈ Mod(T, Lind T ). The rest of the proof is analogous to the proof of completeness for weakly implicative logics (Theorem 1).

div.head: Definition 25 (Prelinearity
div.p: Lemma 10 A weakly implicative logic with LEP has also PP.
Proof Contrapositively: let T χ , then (using LEP) there is linear theory T , such that T χ . Assume that T ϕ → ψ, then obviously T, ϕ → ψ χ .

To reverse this lemma it seems that we need one additional assumption: the logic has to be finitary. However, it is quite obvious that for some infinitary rules the equivalence will hold as well; the question of exact characterization of the class of weakly implicative logics for which the equivalence holds seems to be an interesting open problem.
Lemma 11 A finitary weakly implicative logic with PP has also LEP.
Proof Let ||L|| = κ, we enumerate all pairs of formulae by ordinals < κ, T 0 = T. We construct theories T μ using transfinite recursion. Let T μ = ν<μ T ν .

Observe that if T ν ϕ for each ν < μ then T μ ϕ as well (the logic is finitary). We know that either T μ ∪ {ϕ μ → ψ μ } ϕ or T μ ∪ {ψ μ → ϕ μ } ϕ (otherwise using PP we get contradiction with T μ ϕ), define T μ accordingly (as either T μ ∪ {ϕ μ → ψ μ } or T μ ∪ {ψ μ → ϕ μ } to keep ϕ unprovable). Finally, define T = T κ ; obviously T ϕ and T is linear.

div.head: Theorem 3 (Equivalent characterization)
div.p: Let L be a finitary weakly implicative logic. Then the following are equivalent: ,C,a). Let B = (A, D) be an ordered L-matrix and ≤ its matrix order. We define a new set of propositional variables of the same cardinality as A (thus there is a bijection sending a ∈ A to v a ∈ VAR ) and a new logic L in the language L = (VAR , C, a) and prove that it has PP (thus using Lemma 11 we get that it has LEP as well). We distinguish two cases.
First, let us assume that |A| ≤ |VAR|. We define VAR as a subset of VAR of the same cardinality as A and we define logic L as the restriction of the L to FOR L , i.e.,
div.formula: T L ϕ iff T L ϕ (for T ∪ {ϕ} ⊆ FOR L ). Assume that T, ϕ → ψ L χ and T, ψ → ϕ L χ , then also T, ϕ → ψ L χ and T, ψ → ϕ L χ .
div.p: Using PP for L we get T L χ . Definition of the logic L completes the proof.

Second, let us assume that |A| > |VAR|. We define VAR as a superset of VAR of the same cardinality as A. We define T L ϕ iff there is finite subset T ⊆ T and σ ∈ SUB L such that σ (T ) ∪{σ ϕ} ⊆ FOR L and σ (T ) L σ ϕ. From [5] (remark after Exercise 0.3.3) we know that L is a finitary logic (in the sense of our definition) and it is a conservative extension of L (thus L is a weakly implicative logic). Now we show that L has PP. Let us assume that T, ϕ → ψ L χ and T, ψ → ϕ L χ . As L is a finitary logic we know that there is a finite ). Finally, we observe that for each formula ϕ there is a ∈ A, such that T ϕ ↔ v a .
div.formula: T ⊆ T such that T , ϕ → ψ L χ and T , ψ → ϕ L χ . Obviously there is a substitution σ ∈ SUB L such that σ (T ) ∪ {σ ϕ, σ ψ, σ χ} ⊆ FOR L . Thus also σ (T ), σ ϕ → σ ψ L σ χ and σ (T ), σ ψ → σ ϕ L σ χ (because L is a logic).
div.p: Let us define the set I of all linear theories extending T. Next we define L-matrix X = S∈I Lind S (direct product of Lindenbaum-Tarski matrices). Finally, we define
div.formula: f (a) = ([v a ] S ) S∈I . Now we show that f is an embedding of B into X: since for each S ∈ I we have [v c B (a 1 ,...,a n ) ] S = [c(v a 1 , . . . , v a n )] S = c Lind S ([v a 1 ] S , . . . , [v a n ] S ) and so we get f (c B (a 1 , . . . , a n )) = (c Lind S ([v a 1 ] S , . . . , [v a n ] S )) S∈I = c X (f (a 1 ), . . . , f (a n )).
div.p: Since obviously a ∈ D entails that f (a) ∈ D X (from a ∈ D we have T v a and so S v a and thus [v a ] S ∈ D Lind S for each S ∈ I) we know that f is a morphism. It remains to be shown that f is one-one: from a = b we get that either a ≤ b or b ≤ a. Let us assume that a ≤ b then T v a → v b , using Lemma 11 we know that there is a linear theory
div.formula: S ∈ I such that S v a → v b thus [v a ] S ≤ Lind S [v b ] S and so f (a) ≤ X f (b).
div.p: Finally, we observe that for each S we have π S (f (A)) = L S (just recall that for each ϕ there is a ∈ A, such that T ϕ ↔ v a ).

Since Lind S is linearly ordered L-matrix for each S ∈ I and B can be embedded into a direct product of (Lind S ) S∈I in the way that π S (f (A)) = L S . We conclude that B is a subdirect product of linearly ordered L-matrices.
4. → 1. : Trivial.

div.head: Lemma 12
div.p: Let L be a fuzzy logic. Then (ϕ → ψ) i → χ , (ψ → ϕ) j → χ L χ for each natural i and j.
Proof
div.formula: Let T = {(ϕ → ψ) i → χ , (ψ → ϕ) j → χ }.
div.p: Obviously T, ϕ → ψ χ and T, ψ → ϕ χ . Since each fuzzy logic has PP the proof is done.
The proof of the following important lemma is obvious. It allows us to speak about the weakest fuzzy logic with some property (e.g., being stronger than some known logic).

div.head: Lemma 13 (Intersection)
div.p: The intersection of an arbitrary system of fuzzy logics is a fuzzy logic.

div.head: Lemma 14 (Conservative expansion) Let L be a fuzzy logic, which is a conservative expansion of a finitary logic L. Then L is fuzzy logic.
div.p: Proof We know that L has PP, we show that L has PP as well and because L is finitary we get that L is fuzzy. Let us take theory T and formulae ϕ, ψ, χ in the language of L. Assume that T, ϕ → ψ L χ and T, ψ → ϕ L χ , then also T, ϕ → ψ L χ and T, ψ → ϕ L χ . Using PP for L we get T L χ . Conservativeness completes the proof.
This lemma can also be formulated as: a finitary fragment of a fuzzy logic is a fuzzy logic. We can easily prove the "other direction" of this lemma:

div.head: Lemma 15 (Axiomatic extension) An axiomatic extension of any fuzzy logic is a fuzzy logic.
div.p: Recall that we use term "extension" if both logics have the same language. This assumption can be omitted if we assume some additional properties of the logic in question. However, we do not deal with possible generalizations of this lemma in this paper.

div.head: Adding rules and connectives
div.p: In this section, we introduce some important additional rules (see Tables 1,2) and some additional connectives (see Table 3). The basic rules, we consider in this paper, correspond to the well known structural rules of exchange, contraction and weakening. We formulate them as rules, however in some situation we can use their stronger forms -as axioms. To do this in a general way we present the following definition. Definition 27 Let R be a unary deduction rule of the form ϕ ψ. By the corresponding axiom we understand axiom ϕ → ψ; we denote it as R ax .
div.formula: ϕ ψ → ϕ W Weakening ϕ → (ψ → χ) ψ → (ϕ → χ) E Exchange ϕ → (ϕ → ψ) ϕ → ψ C Contraction Table 2 Addition rules Consecution Symbol Name (ϕ → ψ) → χ , (ψ → ϕ) → χ χ PL Prelinearity ϕ → ((ϕ → ψ) → ψ) As Assertion ϕ → ψ (ψ → χ) → (ϕ → χ) Sf Suffixing ψ → χ (ϕ → ψ) → (ϕ → χ) Pf Prefixing ϕ → (ϕ → ϕ) M M i n g l e
div.p: Of course if L is weakly implicative logic, then L ϕ → ψ entails ϕ L ψ, i.e., if R ax ∈ L, then R ∈ L. Recall that in the literature some of the axioms are known under different names.

This section is just a (small) sketch of a huge work to be done. The ultimate goal is to characterize the known logics and put them into our context with modularly designed Hilbert's style calculi. Having this done, we identify which of them are fuzzy, or we find minimal fuzzy logics extending some known logics (e.g., minimal fuzzy logic over Intuitionistic logic is Gödel logic, minimal fuzzy logic over Full Lambek calculus with exchange and weakening is MTL logic, etc.) A lot of work in this direction can be found in Restall's book [14] (of course for logic in general, he does not deal with the fuzzy logic in any form).

Having a stronger logic/language (usually) leads to a simplified semantics, e.g., having 1 we can replace matrices with ordered structures (the designated set will be the upper cone of 1 B ); having one of the lattice connectives we can even work with algebras, thus being able to use the powerful methods of Abstract Algebraic Logics (which, of course, we can use anyway, but some theorems of AAL hold in algebraizable logics only). There are other possible simplification of the semantics allowed by adding some structural rules (weakening leads to algebraic semantics, exchange to ordered structures, with ϕ being "valid" iff e(ϕ → ϕ) ≤ e(ϕ), etc.).

As mentioned above, we consider the connectives from Table 3. We use usual symbols and names for them and we want them to behave "as they should". So we introduce the so called matching rules for the particular connective. This is to be understood as a convention -e.g., we only state that we use some symbols in some meaning, we do not make claims like: each feasible connective of "conjunction" must behave according to the rules ….

For particular matching rules, see Table 4. There is a special connective , whose matching rules (Table 5) can look suspicious and so we present them in Sect. 6, where we try to give some intuitions for their introduction.

There are many interesting interplays between the rules we introduce (e.g., in the presence of the residuation rule we can prove that the residuation axiom is equivalent to the associativity axiom for &).

Definition 28 Let Q be a set of consecutions and L a weakly implicative logic in L. We say that L is a Q-weakly implicative logic in L if Q ⊆ L and some of the connectives from the set { , 0, 1, ⊥, ∧, ∨, &, , } are in L, then their matching rules are elements of L.
div.formula: ψ&ϕ → χ ϕ → (ψ χ) R -Residuation ϕ → (ψ → χ) ϕ&ψ → χ R Residuation & ϕ → ψ ϕ ψ Imp Implications ϕ → Tr Verum ex quolibet ⊥ → ϕ Fa Ex falso quodlibet ⊥ ϕ 1 → ϕ PP Push and pop 1 ϕ → χ , ψ → χ ϕ ∨ ψ → χ ∨1 Supremality ∨ ϕ → ϕ ∨ ψ ∨2 Maximality ∨ ϕ ∨ ψ → ψ ∨ ϕ ∨3 Commutativity ∨ χ → ϕ, χ → ψ χ → ϕ ∧ ψ ∧1 Infimality ∧ ϕ ∧ ψ → ϕ ∧2 Minimality ∧ ϕ ∧ ψ → ψ ∧ ϕ ∧3 Commutativity ∧ Table 5 Matching rules for Consecution Symbol Name (ϕ → ψ) → ( ϕ → ψ) 1 -Monotonicity ϕ → ϕ 2 -Reflexivity ϕ → ϕ 3 -Transitivity ϕ → ( ψ → ϕ) W -Weakening ( ϕ → ( ϕ → ψ)) → ( ϕ → ψ) C -Contraction ( ϕ → ( ψ → χ)) → ( ψ → ( ϕ → χ)) E -Exchange ϕ ϕ ( NEC) Necessitation
div.p: We say that L is a Q-fuzzy logic if L is a fuzzy logic and L is a Q-weakly implicative logic.
Observe that {W}-weakly implicative logics are exactly Rasiowa's implicative logics. To simplify things, we will write that "L is a Q-logic" instead of "L is a Q-weakly implicative logic".
Definition 29 Let L be a propositional language. We denote the weakest Q-logic in L as MIN L (Q) and the weakest fuzzy Q-logic as FUZZ L (Q).

Both definitions are sound thanks to Lemmas 5 and 13. If L consists of the connective → only we use the symbol MIN (Q) instead of MIN → (Q) (analogously for FUZZ(Q)). In general if we usually do not add → to the list of the connectives in the symbol MIN L (Q), because → is a connective of any weakly implicative logic. Obviously MIN (Q) = p WIL∪Q , i.e., the presentation of MIN (Q) results from the presentation of WIL by adding consecutions from Q Table 6 puts some known logics (we assume the reader to know the usual Hilbert style calculi for these logics) into our context. To prove soundness of this table we need to prove that in the presence of Sf ax and E we get the residuation axioms from the residuation rules. We show one direction:
div.formula: (i) (ϕ → (ψ → χ)) → (ϕ → (ψ → χ)) (Ref) (ii) ϕ → ((ϕ → (ψ → χ)) → (ψ → χ)) (i) and E (iii) ϕ → (ψ → ((ϕ → (ψ → χ)) → χ)) (ii), E ax , (WT) (iv) ϕ&ψ → ((ϕ → (ψ → χ)) → χ) (iii) and residuation rule (v) (ϕ → (ψ → χ)) → (ϕ&ψ → χ) (iv), E
div.p: In the rest of this section we explore consequences of having disjunction in the language and so we assume that ∨ ∈ L for all languages we encounter from now on. We will see that disjunction allows us to express several concepts of this paper in ways more usual in the literature.
Lemma 16 Let L be a weakly implicative logic. Then ϕ ∨ ψ, ϕ → ψ ψ.
Proof We give a formal proof:
div.formula: (i) ϕ → ψ, ψ → ψ ϕ ∨ ψ → ψ ∨1 (ii) ϕ ∨ ψ, ϕ → ψ ϕ ∨ ψ → ψ (i) and (Ref) (iii) ϕ ∨ ψ, ϕ → ψ ψ (ii) and (MP) Table 6 Known logics L Q MIN L (Q) ⊥, & ∨ Sf ax , E, W, C Intuitionistic logic , ⊥, 1, 0, &, ∧, ∨ Sf, Pf Full Lambek ⊥, & Sf ax , E, W, C, PL Gödel logic ⊥, &, ∧ Sf ax , E, W, PL MTL logic &, ∧ Sf ax , E, W, PL MTLH logic
div.p: Now we define the notion of prime theory. It is more known and more widely used concept than the concept of linear theory. However, we will see that both notions coincide in fuzzy logics.

div.head: Definition 30 (Prime theory) Let L be a weakly implicative logic. A theory T is
div.formula: prime if T ϕ or T ψ whenever T ϕ ∨ ψ.
div.p: Definition 31 (Prime extension) A weakly implicative logic L has the prime extension property (PEP) if for each theory T and formula ϕ such that T ϕ there is a prime theory T such that T ⊆ T and T ϕ.
Definition 32 (Proof by cases) A weakly implicative logic L has the proof by cases property (PCP) if for each theory T we get T, ϕ ∨ ψ χ whenever T, ϕ χ and T, ψ χ .

Observe that the above defined principles PCP and PEP differ from the seemingly analogous principles PP and LEP. For example Intuitionistic logic has both PCP and PEP but does not have the other two. Let us examine this in more details:
Lemma 17 Let L be a weakly implicative logic. Then:
div.formula: 1. each linear theory is prime; 2. if L has PP, then (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ); 3. if (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ), then each prime theory is linear; 4. if L has PP, then L has PCP; 5. if (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ) and L has PCP, then L has PP. Proof 1. Let T ϕ ∨ ψ.
div.p: Since T is linear we know that T ϕ → ψ or T ψ → ϕ. Thus (using Lemma 16) we get T ψ or T ϕ.

div.head: From ∨2 and (MP) we easily get
div.formula: (ϕ → ψ) (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ) and (ψ → ϕ) (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ). PP completes the proof. 3. Trivial. 4.
div.p: Let T be a theory such that T, ϕ χ and T, ψ χ . Using Lemma 16 we know that T, ϕ ∨ ψ, ϕ → ψ ψ and T, ϕ ∨ ψ, ψ → ϕ ϕ. Thus T, ϕ ∨ ψ, ϕ → ψ χ and T, ϕ ∨ ψ, ψ → ϕ χ . PP and part 2 completes the proof. 5. From T, ϕ → ψ χ and T, ψ → ϕ χ we get T,
div.formula: (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ) χ . Knowing that (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ), we get T χ .
div.p: This lemma has three interesting corollaries.

div.head: Corollary 3 In a fuzzy logic the theory T is prime iff T is linear.
div.p: Corollary 4 Let L be a logic and L (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ). Then L fuzzy iff L has PEP.

div.head: Corollary 5
div.p: Let L be a finitary logic and L (ϕ → ψ) ∨ (ψ → ϕ). Then L is fuzzy iff L has PCP.

div.head: Expansions of BCI and deduction theorem
div.p: In this section we deal with logics expanding the well-known logic BCI. This logic was first studied by Meredith (see the original paper [11]) and it is a generalization of much wider studied logic BCK (for more details see [3]) We first make some rather simple syntactical observation about possible axiomatizations of this logic by exploring the (non-)difference between the rule and its axiomatic form (for Sf, Pf, and E). Then we deal with general form of the (local) deduction theorem for weakly implicative logic. This theorem gives us (in some cases) an alternative equivalent definition of the class of (weakly implicative) fuzzy logics.
Let us recall that BCI is an implicational fragment of intuitionistic linear logic and has the following presentation (we use the classical names for axioms Sf ax , E ax , and (Ref)):
Definition 33 The BCI logic has the following presentation:
div.formula: B (ϕ → ψ) → ((ψ → χ) → (ϕ → χ)) C (ϕ → (ψ → χ)) → (ψ → (ϕ → χ)) I ϕ → ϕ (MP) ϕ, ϕ → ψ ψ.
div.p: The following lemma shows the interplay between transitivity and exchange, in fact we are giving alternative axiomatization for BCI. Some of them have been already described in the literature.

div.head: Lemma 18
div.p: The following logics are equivalent:
div.formula: 1. BCI logic 2. MIN ({Sf ax , E ax }) 3. MIN ({Pf ax , E ax }) 4. MIN ({Pf, E ax }) 5. MIN ({Sf ax , E}) 6. MIN ({Pf ax , E}) 7. MIN ({Sf ax , As}).
div.p: Proof We show that each logic is stronger than the next one (cyclicly):
div.formula: 1. ⊇ 2.: We have to show (Cng → ) but this is almost straightforward. 2. ⊇ 3.: Trivial. 3. ⊇ 4.: Trivial. 4. ⊇ 5.: All we need to show is MIN ({Pf,E ax }) Sf ax : (i) (ψ → χ) → (ψ → χ) (Ref) (ii) ψ → ((ψ → χ) → χ) (i), E ax , (MP) (iii) (ϕ → ψ) → (ϕ → ((ψ → χ) → χ)) (ii), Pf (iv) (ϕ → ((ψ → χ) → χ)) → ((ψ → χ) → (ϕ → χ)) E ax (v) (ϕ → ψ) → ((ψ → χ) → (ϕ → χ))
div.p: (iii), (iv), Pf 5. ⊇ 6.: Trivial. 6. ⊇ 7.: Trivial.

div.head: ⊇ 1.: All we need to show is MIN
div.p: Notice two open problems: what about logic MIN ({Sf, E ax }) and logic MIN ({Pf ax , As})? Table 7 puts some known logics into our context (we list the axioms which have to be added to BCI). We can add all of them as rules or axioms -in the presence of exchange and Syllogism Law (Sf ax ) these two options are equivalent -as shown by the following observation:
Lemma 19 It holds:
div.formula: 1. MIN (Sf ax , E) = MIN (Sf ax , E ax ) 2. MIN (Sf ax , E, W) = MIN (Sf ax , E ax , W ax ) 3. MIN (Sf ax , E, C) = MIN (Sf ax , E ax , C ax ).
div.p: Proof Part 1 was shown in Lemma 18. Part 2 is easy. To prove part 3 we show that MIN (Sf ax ,E,C) C ax :
div.formula: (i) (ϕ → (ϕ → ψ)) → (ϕ → (ϕ → ψ)) (Ref) (ii) ϕ → ((ϕ → (ϕ → ψ)) → (ϕ → ψ)) (i) and E. (iii) ϕ → (ϕ → ((ϕ → (ϕ → ψ)) → ψ)) (ii), E ax , Sf ax (iv) ϕ → ((ϕ → (ϕ → ψ)) → ψ) (iii) and C (v) (ϕ → (ϕ → ψ)) → (ϕ → ψ)
div.p: (iv) and E Before we proceed further, let us observe some properties of BCI. The proofs are easy (by induction).

Lemma 20 It holds: Now we present an important definition -the deduction theorem -for a rather wide class of weakly implicative logic. We present it in an unusual form. Our formulation allows us to show exactly which logics have this deduction theorem. We say that P is an AX -proof of T ϕ instead that P is a proof of ϕ in theory T in a presentation AX . We also say that ϕ is an element (a leaf) of the proof instead say that ϕ is a label of some node (leaf) of the proof. Finally we define: Definition 34 Let L be a logic and AX an axiomatic system. We say that AX is MP-based if (MP) is the only deduction rule of AX . The logic L is MP-based if it has some MP-based presentation.
div.formula: 1. BCI (ϕ n → (ψ m → χ)) → (ψ m → (ϕ n → χ)) 2. BCI (ϕ n → ψ) → ((ψ → χ) → (ϕ n → χ)).
div.p: Definition 35 Let L be a logic. We say that L has Implicational Deduction Theorem (DT → ) if L has a MP-based presentation AX and for each theory T, formulae ϕ, ψ, and for each AX -proof P of T, ϕ ψ there is an AX -proof P of T ϕ n → ψ, where n is the number of occurrences of ϕ in the leaves of the proof P and each χ ∈ T occurs in the leaves of P the same number of times as in the leaves of P .
Observe that each logic with DT → has also the deduction theorem in more usual (in non-classical logics) form. The proofs of the following lemma and corollary are almost straightforward.

div.head: Corollary 6
div.p: Each logic with DT → has the so-called local deduction theorem (LDT): for each theory T and formulae ϕ, ψ: T, ϕ ψ iff there is n such that T ϕ n → ψ.
Lemma 21 Each finitary logic with LDT is MP-based.

It can be shown that there is a weakly implicative logic with LDT but without DT → . Now we present a sufficient and necessary condition for L to have DT → . This theorem allows us to present a slightly more natural formulation of DT → . The thorough investigation of the concept of deduction theorems inside the weakly implicative logics is a subject of an upcoming paper by the author.

div.head: Theorem 4 (Deduction theorem)
div.p: Let L be a logic. Then L has DT → iff L is MP-based and L is an expansion of BCI.

Proof First direction: all we have to do is to show that L Sf ax and L E ax (the rest is the immediate consequence of the definition of DT → ). Observe that ϕ, ψ, ϕ → (ψ → χ) L χ and each of the premises is used exactly once, applying DT → three times we get L E ax . Since ϕ, ϕ → ψ, ψ → χ L χ and each of the premises is used exactly once, applying DT → three times we get L Sf ax . Reverse direction: we use the induction over the AX -proof P. We show that for each formula χ in P the condition from Definition 35 holds. Since the precise formulation of the proof of the induction step would be extremely technical, we give (an unnecessarily) detailed proof of the initial steps and leave the rest to the reader. 1. χ is in a leaf of P and χ = ϕ. The proof of T, ϕ χ is one element tree (consisting of the formula ϕ). Since ϕ → ϕ we get T ϕ → ϕ. Since ϕ occurs once in the proof of T, ϕ χ and no formula of T occurs in the proof of T ϕ → ϕ our condition holds. 2. χ is in a leaf of P and χ = ϕ. Thus χ ∈ T or χ is an axiom. Again the proof of T, ϕ χ is one element tree (consisting of the formula χ ), the same tree is a proof of T ϕ 0 → χ . Observe that our condition holds (we have not used the formula ϕ and if χ ∈ T we used χ exactly once in both proofs and no other formula from T occurs in any of the proofs). 3. χ has predecessors ψ 2 = ψ 1 → χ and ψ 1 . Using the induction property we get T ϕ n → (ψ 1 → χ) and T ϕ m → ψ 1 . From Lemma 20 (1). we get T ψ 1 → (ϕ n → χ) and Lemma 20 (2). gives us T ϕ m → (ϕ n → χ).
Thus T ϕ m+n → χ . Observe that our condition holds.

We have proved even more: given proof of ψ in T, ϕ, we have a constructive procedure which produces the proof of ϕ n → ψ in T. The proofs of the following two corollaries are almost straightforward. The first one formulates DT → in a way more resembling the usual formulations of deduction theorems (it mentions the number of occurrences of ϕ but we do not mention the formulas from T). It also entails an interesting open problem: what happen if we formulate it for two or one formula only?
Corollary 7 Let L be a logic. Then L has DT → iff L has a MP-based presentation AX and for each theory T, formulae ϕ 1 , ϕ 2 , ϕ 3 , ψ we have: T, ϕ 1 , ϕ 2 , ϕ 3 ψ iff T ϕ
, where n i are numbers of occurrences of ϕ i in the leaves of some AX -proof of T, ϕ 1 , ϕ 2 , ϕ 3 ψ.

div.head: Corollary 8
div.p: Let L be a finitary logic expanding BCI. Then the following are equivalent:
div.formula: -L has DT → -L has LDT -L is MP-based.
div.p: In the presence of LDT we can prove the "converse" of Lemma 12. Thus we have an equivalent definition of fuzzy logics in some class of logics.
Lemma 22 Let L be a finitary logic with LDT. Then L is a fuzzy logic iff for each i and j it holds:
div.formula: (ϕ → ψ) i → χ , (ψ → ϕ) j → χ L χ .
div.p: Proof One direction is just Lemma 12. To prove the other direction we only show that L has PP. Assume that T, ϕ → ψ χ and T, ϕ → ψ χ . By LDT we get T (ϕ → ψ) i → χ and T (ψ → ϕ) j → χ and so we have T χ .

At the end of this subsection we present an infinite axiomatic system for the weakest fuzzy {Sf ax , E, W}-logic. The question whether there is a finite system seems to be open. Recall that logic BCK is axiomatized by adding W ax to the axioms of BCI. Again, we use here the classical names for axioms Sf ax , E ax , and W ax .

div.head: Definition 36
div.p: The fuzzy BCK logic (FBCK) has the following presentation:
div.formula: B (ϕ → ψ) → ((ψ → χ) → (ϕ → χ)) C (ϕ → (ψ → χ)) → (ψ → (ϕ → χ)) K ϕ → (ψ → ϕ) F n ((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) → (((ψ → ϕ) n → χ) → χ) for all n (MP) ϕ, ϕ → ψ ψ.
div.p: Observe that FBCK = MIN (Sf ax , E, W, F n ). Using Lemma 18 we could write several different equivalent axiomatic systems. Also observe that ordered FBCK-matrices are exactly BCK-algebras satisfying axioms F n .
Theorem 5 FBCK = FUZZ({Sf ax , E, W}).

Proof First, we show that FBCK is a fuzzy logic. Using Theorem 3 it is enough to show that FBCK has PP. Let T, ϕ → ψ χ and T, ψ → ϕ χ , then using LDT (FBCK has LDT thanks to Corollary 8) we get that T (ϕ → ψ) m → χ and T (ψ → ϕ) n → χ for some n and m. Let us take t = max(m, n), using W we get the T (ϕ → ψ) t → χ and T (ψ → ϕ) t → χ , axiom F t completes the proof. Now we have to show that each fuzzy logic extending BCK proves F n . We recall that each fuzzy logic has PP. Now observe that
div.formula: (i) ((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) → ((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) (Ref) (ii) (ϕ → ψ) n → (((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) → χ) (i) and Lemma 20 1. (iii) ϕ → ψ (((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) → χ) (ii) (iv) ϕ → ψ ((ψ → ϕ) n → χ) → (((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) → χ) (iii) and K (v) ϕ → ψ ((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) → (((ψ → ϕ) n → χ) → χ)
div.p: (iv) and C
By replacing ϕ and ψ in (iv) we get:
div.formula: (vi) ψ → ϕ ((ϕ → ψ) n → χ) → (((ψ → ϕ) n → χ) → χ)
div.p: Since L has PP we get F n .
Obviously BCK = MIN (Sf ax , E, W) and thus we get the corollary:
Corollary 9 FBCK is the weakest fuzzy logic stronger than BCK.

We can alter the axioms F n by using two different natural numbers m, n as "exponents", we get axioms F m,n . If we add axioms F m,n to the BCI logic, we get a fuzzy logic (by Lemma 22). However, we are not able to prove the converse statement, i.e., that this logic is the minimal fuzzy logic over BCI.

div.head: Corollary 10
div.p: The quasivariety of BCK-algebras generated by the class of BCKchains is axiomatized by adding the identities
div.formula: ((x → y) n → z) → (((y → x) n → z) → z) = 1 for each n.
div.p: This result is achieved in the paper by García Olmedo and Rodríguez Salas [9], who proposed there a concept of linearization of a logical systems (of an algebraizable logic). Their approach is rather different from ours in several aspects. They take an algebraizable logic and the quasivariety Q of the algebras constituting the equivalent algebraic semantics for the original logic. Then they define a logic given by the quasivariety generated by the chains from Q. Their paper is utilizing a rather heavy algebraic machinery to get the result, whereas we get it as a rather simple consequence of the deduction theorem.
Again, more thorough examination and comparing both approaches will be a subject of the subsequent paper.

div.head: The connective
div.p: The connective is special and its variants appear in many non-classical logics (usually fulfilling some additional assumptions): it appears in the so-called symmetrical Heyting algebras (see [12]); it corresponds to the globalization of Intuitionistic logic (see [15]) and exponential in linear logic (see [14]), it has some properties of general modalities, and it is know as Baaz delta in fuzzy logics (see [1]). Roughly speaking, this connective allows us controlled usage of the structural rules. In this section we assume that is an element of all the propositional languages L (unless the opposite is explicitly mentioned). Now we present the analog of Definition 35 and prove the analog of Theorem 4. However, the connective allows us much simpler formulations (resembling the deduction theorem of modal logic S4). In the following definition and theorem we understand L as an arbitrary weakly implicative logic (not necessarily with matching rules 1, 2, 3, W, C, E, and (NEC)).
Definition 37 Let L be a weakly implicative logic. We say that L has delta deduction theorem (DT ) if for each theory T and formulae ϕ, ψ we have: T, ϕ ψ iff T ϕ → ψ.

Now we present a sufficient and necessary condition for L to have DT . And we also show that in each weakly implicative logic with DT the matching rules for hold. Thus we can see that our matching rules for are "tailored" to allow us to prove DT . Theorem 6 (Deduction theorem) Let L be a finitary logic. Then L has DT iff L has some presentation AX , where (MP) and (NEC) are the only deduction rules and all the matching rules for are provable in L.
Proof First direction: assume that L has DT , then obviously L has presentation where (MP) and (NEC) are the only deduction rules (just replace each rule ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n ψ with the axiom
All we have to do is to show that the matching rules for hold:

-(NEC): From ϕ → ϕ we get ϕ ϕ (using DT ). -1: From ϕ, ϕ → ψ ψ we get ϕ, ϕ → ψ ψ (using (NEC)). Applying DT twice completes the proof. -2: From ϕ ϕ we get ϕ → ϕ (using DT ). -3: From ϕ ϕ we get ϕ → ϕ (using (NEC) twice and DT ).
Recall that in the presence of ⊥ we can define the derived connective negation as ¬ϕ = ϕ → ⊥. Now we show some rather trivial properties of logics with and ⊥ in the language.
Lemma 26 Let L be a language, ⊥ ∈ L, and L a logic in L. Then
Proof The only non-trivial claim is part 1 (part 4 is an instance of -contraction). We give a formal proof.

div.head: and (WT)
div.p: Let us assume from now on that ⊥ is an element of all propositional languages L. The reader familiar with fuzzy logics with can notice that matching rules are somehow "weak", has more properties in the "fuzzy" setting, which do not hold in general. In the rest of this section we add some additional rules for to get the known fuzzy logics with . We start by showing that fuzzy logic L with L (¬ ϕ → ϕ) → ϕ has some interesting properties.
Lemma 27 Let L be a fuzzy logic in L such that L (¬ ϕ → ϕ) → ϕ. Then:
1. For each linearly ordered L-matrix B holds:
div.formula: B x = 1 B if 1 B ≤ B x and B x = ⊥ B otherwise. 2. L has DT . 3. T, ϕ χ and T, ¬ ϕ χ entails T χ . 4. (1 → ⊥) → ⊥ and (⊥ → ⊥) → 1 iff ¬ ϕ → ¬ ϕ. 5. ¬ ϕ → ¬ ϕ iff ¬ (ϕ → ψ) → (ψ → ϕ).
div.p: Proof 1. We omit the subscripts B in this proof. Let 1 ≤ x, then obviously 1 ≤ x (using (NEC)). Using W we get 1 ≤ 1 ≤ x → 1, thus x ≤ 1.

If x < 1, then x < 1 as well (from ( 2) we know x ≤ x). Since we have ¬ x → x ≤ x we also have ¬ x > x (otherwise 1 ≤ ¬ x → x and so 1 ≤ x-a contradiction). Observe that from part 4 of Lemma 26 we get ( x → ¬ x) ≤ ¬ x. We know that x ≤ ¬ x so ( x → ¬ x) = 1 and so 1 ≤ x → ⊥. Finally, x ≤ ⊥.

2. One direction is obvious. We show the reverse one contrapositively: if T ϕ → ψ, then there is linearly ordered L-matrix B and B-model e of T and e( ϕ → ψ) < 1 (again we omit the subscripts B). Then obviously 1 ≤ e(ϕ) (otherwise e( ϕ) = ⊥ and we would get 1 ≤ e( ϕ → ψ)-a contradiction), thus e( ϕ) = 1 and so 1 → e(ψ) = e( ϕ → ψ) < 1. So we know that e is a B-model of T, ϕ and e(ψ) < 1. Thus T, ϕ ψ.

3. From our assumption, (NEC), 1 we get (¬ ψ → ψ) → ψ, we also know ( ψ → ¬ ψ) → ¬ ψ from part 4 of Lemma 26. Thus whenever we prove T, ψ χ and T¬ ψ χ we get by DT and previous observation that T (¬ ψ → ψ) → χ and T ( ψ → ¬ ψ) → χ . Lemma 23 gives us T χ .

4. Observe that from (1 → ⊥) → ⊥ we get ¬1 → χ and also from (⊥ → ⊥) → 1 we get χ ¬⊥ → χ . We use part 3 of this lemma: first notice that ϕ 1 ↔ ϕ so ϕ ¬ ϕ → ¬1 and thus ϕ ¬ ϕ → ¬ ϕ. Second, we know that ¬ ϕ ⊥ ↔ ϕ and thus ¬ ϕ ¬ ϕ → ¬⊥. since ¬ ϕ ¬ ϕ we get ¬ ϕ ¬ ϕ → ¬ ϕ. To prove the reverse direction just set ϕ = 1 in one case and ϕ = ⊥ in the second one. We get ¬ 1 → ¬ 1 and ¬ ⊥ → ¬ ⊥. Lemma 26 completes the proof.
5. We use Lemma 23. First, observe ψ → ϕ ¬ (ϕ → ψ) → (ψ → ϕ) (using W, 3, and DT ) and so ψ
div.formula: → ϕ ¬ (ϕ → ψ) → (ψ → ϕ) (using ¬ ϕ → ¬ ϕ). Recall that ϕ → ψ (ϕ → ψ) ↔ 1 and since we know (1 → ⊥) → χ (from part 4 of this lemma) we get ϕ → ψ ¬ (ϕ → ψ) → (ψ → ϕ).
div.p: The reverse direction: first set ϕ = ⊥, ψ = 1, and get ¬ (⊥ → 1) → (1 → ⊥). Observe that (⊥ → 1) ↔ 1 (using DT ) and so we have Observe that part 1 of the previous lemma holds even without assumption that L is a fuzzy logic and that part 2 has an interesting corollary:
Corollary 12 Let L be a finitary fuzzy logic such that L (¬ ϕ → ϕ) → ϕ. Then L has a presentation where (MP) and (NEC) are the only deduction rules.
Of course, we even know this presentation: just replace each rule of the form ϕ 1 , . . . , ϕ n ψ with the axiom

The previous lemma also shows an important difference between operation in fuzzy logics and the so-called globalization known from Intuitionistic logic. Let us (for now) use symbol for globalization. Let us recall that for each Heyting algebra B holds: B x = 1 B if 1 B ≤ B x and B x = ⊥ B otherwise. (It can be easily shown that extensions of Intuitionistic logic by connective with this semantics proves all matching rules for .) This condition looks similar to that from part 1 of the previous lemma but there is a huge difference: the latter condition speaks about linear matrices only! Since the fuzzy logics have SDP, each non-linear matrix is a subdirect product of linear ones and so the interpretation of on this non-linear matrix will not behave according to the condition for (easy computation). Now we try to formulate the "essence" of the connective , when used in fuzzy logics.

Definition 38 Let L be a language such that ⊥, ∈ L and L a fuzzy logic in L. We say that L is a logic with Baaz delta if for each formula in language {→, ⊥, 1}, if we define substitution σ (v) = v then L σ ϕ iff ϕ is a theorem of classical logic.

Obviously, not each logic with connective is logic with Baaz delta (take Intuitionistic logic, and in all Heyting algebras interpret as identity). Observe that if L is a logic with Baaz delta, it is consistent. This definition can be viewed as rather peculiar, but we are going to present more convenient alternative definition. The following lemma works for the fuzzy logics only: even if Intuitionistic logic fulfills properties 1-5 from the upcoming definition it is not a logic with Baaz delta, analogously it can be easily shown that Łukasiewicz logic with globalization is not a fuzzy logic and so it is not a logic with Baaz delta.
Lemma 28 Let L be a consistent fuzzy logic. Then L is a fuzzy logic with Baaz delta iff the following holds:
Proof One direction is obvious (only non-trivial part is to show part 1 -to do this just notice that (¬p → p) → p is a theorem of the classical logic).

To prove the converse direction we need to show two things: first, if ϕ is a theorem of the classical logic, then L σ ϕ. We prove this contrapositively: assume that L σ ϕ, then there is linear L-matrix B and B-evaluation e such that e(σ ϕ) < 1. Observe that from Lemma 27 part 1 we know that e( v) is either 1 or ⊥, from the form of the formula σ ϕ and from assumptions 2-5 we know that e(σ ϕ) = ⊥ and if we define the evaluation f (v) = e( v), then f is a classical evaluation not satisfying ϕ.

Second, we need to show that if L σ ϕ, then ϕ is a theorem of the classical logic. We prove this by a contradiction: assume that there is a classical evaluation e, such that e(ϕ) = ⊥. Then there is substitution ρ(v) = e(v) (we identify constants 1 and ⊥ with two truth values of the classical logic) and ρϕ → ⊥ is a theorem of the classical logic. Thus L σ (ρϕ → ⊥) (using the previous direction). Because σ (ρϕ → ⊥) = ρϕ → ⊥ (there are no variables in ρϕ → ⊥) and Assumptions 2-5 we get L ρϕ → ⊥. Since L σ ϕ we also have L ρσ ϕ and so finally ρϕ (because ⊥ ↔ ⊥ and 1 ↔ 1). Thus together we have L ⊥-a contradiction with the consistency of L.

In the literature, it is common that for fuzzy logic L there is defined its conservative expansion by the connective (usually denoted as L ), which is also a fuzzy logic. It is usual that L is a logic with Baaz delta and has DT (even if L has not some variant of the deduction theorem). Now we introduce a general way of expanding the logic L into the logic L . First we give an indirect definition and then we show how to find a presentation of L based on the presentation of L.
Definition 39 Let L be a consistent fuzzy logic in L, ⊥ ∈ L, and ∈ L. By L we denote the weakest fuzzy logic in the language L ∪ { } which has Baaz delta and expands L.

The soundness of this definition is guaranteed by Lemma 13. In the literature, we see other axiomatic systems for logics with Baaz delta than the one which we are going to present. However, this one has several advantages. First, it is formulated in the language with →, ⊥, and only and second, it does not assume any structural rules of the starting logic. (1 → 1) → 1.

Proof Let L be the logic with the above presentation. First we have to show that L is a fuzzy logic with Baaz delta (it obviously expands L). We show that if T L ϕ → χ and T L ¬ ϕ → χ then T L χ . In that case we get (from 4a and 4b) that T L (¬ ϕ → ϕ) → χ and T L ( ϕ → ¬ ϕ) → χ . To complete the proof of this part just observe that because L is a fuzzy logic we know that (ϕ → ψ) → χ , (ψ → ϕ) → χ L χ and so we also have (ϕ → ψ) → χ , (ψ → ϕ) → χ L χ .

We use this observation for T = { (ϕ → ψ) → χ , (ψ → ϕ) → χ }. We have T L (ϕ → ψ) → χ (obvious) and T L ¬ (ϕ → ψ) → χ (by 5). Thus { (ϕ → ψ) → χ , (ψ → ϕ) → χ } L χ . From Theorem 6 we know that L has DT , so L is a fuzzy logic (using Lemma 24). Now we observe that L is a conservative expansion of L (Lemma 27 tells us that any linear L-matrix B, which is counterexample to T ϕ, can be extended into the linear L -matrix B and it is a counterexample as well-since L is fuzzy). So we know that L is consistent (because L is consistent).
Thus we can use Lemma 28 to prove that L is a logic with Baaz delta. Notice that all we need to show is the following:

figure.figDesc: Models) Let L be a propositional language, T a theory in L, and B an L-matrix. We say that a B-evaluation e is a B-model of T if e(ϕ) ∈ D B for each ϕ ∈ T. We denote the class of B-models of T by Mod(T, B). Definition 17 (Semantical consequence) Let L be a logic in L, T a theory in L, and K a class of L-matrices. We say that ϕ is a semantical consequence of T w.r.t. class K if Mod(T, B) = Mod(T ∪ {ϕ}, B) for each B ∈ K; we denote it by T | K ϕ. By T AUT (K) we understand the set {ϕ | ∅ | K ϕ}. figure.head: Lemma 7 Example 1
figure.figDesc: Let L be a weakly implicative logic and B an L-matrix. Then relation ≤ B defined as x ≤ B y iff x → B y ∈ D B is a preorder. Furthermore, its symmetrization x ∼ B y iff x ≤ B y and y ≤ B x is a congruence on A. Finally, the set D B is an upper set w.r.t. ≤ B , i.e., if x ∈ D B and x ≤ B y then y ∈ D B . Let us denote the weakest weakly implicative logic in the language containing only → by WIL. How do the WIL-matrices look like? Let B be a WIL-matrix, we know that ≤ B is an preorder and D B is an upper set. Conversely, let B be a set, ≤ a preorder on B, and D = B an upper set of B w.r.t. ≤. Let ⇒ be any binary operation on B such that x ≤ y iff x ⇒ y ∈ D. Then obviously ((B, ⇒), D) is a WIL-matrix. Furthermore, if ≤ is (total) order, then ((B, ⇒), D) is (linearly) ordered WIL-matrix (see the next definition). Definition 20 (Matrix preorder) Let L be a weakly implicative logic and B an L-matrix. The relation ≤ B defined in the previous lemma is called the matrix preorder of B.

In this paper we assume the Axiom of Choice, and thus we can omit the condition of well ordering of VAR and C.

In fact she uses the name standard systems of implicative extensional propositional calculi and has some additional restrictions (like allowing at most binary connectives only). We use the term implicative logics in its recent meaning, see[8].

div.p: Acknowledgements Special thanks go to Libor B ěhounek for helping me to create the notion of weakly implicative logics in the current general form (by his constant "Do you really need to assume …"). Then, I would like to thank Josep Maria Font for helping me a lot, mainly by pointing me to the important results related to my work which I was not aware of, and for suggesting the name "weakly implicative logics". Finally, I would like to thank to both of them and to Rostislav Horčík and Petr Hájek for the repeated reading of the drafts of this paper and helping me to improve it a lot in many aspects.

So all we have to show are the axioms from group B: to do this, just observe that L has DT (because L is fuzzy and L 4a we can use Lemma 27) and since L ⊆ L , the proof is done.

The presence of the axiom (1 → 1) → 1 seems to be unavoidable, however, under some rather weak additional assumptions we can omit it. One of them is of course the presence of weakening, the other is the presence of Sf (then we get (1 → 1) → (⊥ → 1) and using the known fact that (⊥ → 1) → 1 we would get our axiom). Now we can show that L has some promised nice properties (for the proof just inspect the proof of the previous theorem).
Lemma 29 Let L be a consistent fuzzy logic in L, ∈ L, and ⊥ ∈ L. Then L is a fuzzy logic with DT and Baaz delta, which is a conservative expansion of L.
